Name: A Universe from Nothing: Why There Is Something Rather than Nothing

ReviewList.Text: After seeing the video lecture on Youtube over a year ago, I was excited to find out that Professor Krauss would be releasing a book that, to my assumption, would elaborate on what was discussed in the lecture. It does this, but the majority of the book explains cosmology and quantum physics that is already widely written about by other scientists. It talks about the age, shape, size, and expansion of the universe, relativity, and other things even a casual science reader such as myself have already read and watched documentaries about. There are about three chapters in this book, starting with chapter 4, that have anything to do with the "universe from nothing," and most of those discuss other topics more than the subject I was reading the book for. While there is some setup required to understand the "universe from nothing" parts, what is in the book should be obvious to a person who has read cosmology stuff before. A lot of the book is bragging of the author's achievements, and Richard Dawkins's afterword talks about the book as if it is some classic (along with the usual smug religion-bashing), which it is not. I recommend this book to a person who hasn't already read books and/or watched documentaries about the universe and I do not recommend it to someone who is already familiar with the common topics.

Being a Christian I was a little apprehensive to read. However, having a love for all things science I decided to give it a go. This book is absolutely fascinating and for me is my new go to reference to combat the stupidity that is traditional fundamentalism. It is wonderfully written and is a real tribute to our understanding of the natural world. I hope that you will pick it up and read because as it did for me it will change your perspective on just about everything.

Krauss equivocates on the word "nothing." The basic gist of Krauss's argument is that the relativistic quantum field can have different states kind of like my hand can be flat or it can be balled up in a fist. One possible state of the field is the universe that we know and love. Another possible state of the field is the absence of all matter. It is the latter state which Krauss suggests we may as well call nothing. He understands that it isn't nothing (which he calls the "philosopher's" nothing) and he spends a chapter arguing why his equivocation is justified. His argument to justify his equivocation fails and, hence, Krauss doesn't really inform us how the universe began to exist from nothing. And while it is very interesting to hear how the universe came from SOMETHING (truly it is), it is not nearly as interesting as it would be if he showed how the universe could come to exist uncaused from nothing.

It's hard for me to rate this book, as I found I was unable to understand a considerable amount of it. The parts I did understand were fascinating, but later in the book I was completely lost as to what the author is trying to explain. I found myself reading through paragraph after confusing paragraph just to find out what his conclusion was. So I'd say if you are an armchair scientist (like myself), you will probably not get as much enjoyment out of it as someone who understands particle physics, quantum mechanics, etc. So see my three stars as a rating for the average person wanting to learn more about the universe and not someone well versed in the topics discussed in the book.

First, I'd like to admit that many concepts within quantum physics I have trouble grasping and normally have to take some time to wrap my head around them. Krauss takes the time to not only help readers understand the complexity of these concepts of origin but in a manner that makes it entertaining. Readers will learn about dark energy and matter, anti-matter, why the universe is thought to be flat as opposed to closed or open, and the evidence through history that have built these theories just enough to understand the conclusions current research is showing us. As it is approached on several different occasions throughout the book, the assumption of a supernatural force (i.e. a god) in the process of cosmic origins is irrelevent if not completely superfluous in understanding how the universe came to be. I found the book to answer and explain many questions I had in this field and in such a way I can relay my new found understanding to others so they can understand as well. Recommended to those who even have a simple curiosity as to "why there is something rather than nothing" in our universe.

Lawrence Krauss does a great job making cosmology clear to the layman.  He explains modern scientific understanding of the origin of the universe and emphasizes the tentative nature of such understanding.  We are all answerable to the evidence and if you want to know what the evidence currently says, this is a good place to go.

I liked this book enough to read it twice (so far). It is an easy read and, by and large, Krauss make the difficult concepts understandable. It is of course dumbed down considerably, as there are virtually no equations in the text. Some reviewers had negative things to say about the accuracy of the material due to its simplified style. I have no basis to make statements about accuracy; cosmology and particle physics are not my fields of expertise.

A great thing about this work by Dr. Krauss is it really ties up a lot of questions and concerns people have of the formation of the universe. As with all science though, he doesn't expect you to just take it on faith, and he explains why things are the way they are, and HOW we learned this to be true. He is also clear about what is thought to be known and what is just a decent guess and that is a sincerely refreshing and helpful to people like myself who are just looking for answers. There simply aren't many other books out there which cover the things Dr. Krauss goes over and if you are new to learning about cosmology or the sciences in general, or even if you have a degree in a field, I feel this book could become a standard read in short time because of it's scope and aim to answer one of those fundamental questions of humanity with reality, and not mysticism.

A few of the concepts were a little over my head, but the general concept of the book is easily comprehensible and you will understand the theory of the origin of the universe even if you're not a physicist.
Honestly folks, watch the lecture on 'youtube' (still titled 'Universe from Nothing')- and subsequently buy the book.  Krauss gives a fantastic description of normally esoteric scientific concepts.
Excellent book. Doesn't require university level of physics know how to understand but is still complex and in depth enough to give out new interesting information.
I so much appreciate it when scholars and scientists are able to answer complex questions in language I can comprehend.  Thank you so much Lawrence Krauss!
Perhaps a scientific bent would help, which I don't have. So a great deal went over my head, but overall I learnt a lot, so it was worth the effort.

"A Universe From Nothing" by Lawrence M. Krauss.  This is a good, honest book by a physicist (cosmologist) who tries very hard to explain the staggering impact of discoveries in physics over the past century--inflation, the Big Bang, the microwave background and quantum fluctuations, a flat universe, dark matter/energy making up 99% of the universe and providing a negative gravitational pressure/energy that provides for continuing expansion of the universe, a calculation of the age of the universe at 13.72 billion years, etc.-- totally changing our perception of reality. He argues that space and time not only can, but must, come from  nothing (no mass, no energy, no space) via quantum fluctuations and inflation.  He includes a good jibe against theologians and string theorists alike--"physicists don't invent things they can't observe to explain things they can", but incongruously seems to like multiverses.  The book requires study, not just reading, but it is the best book of which I am aware for explaining what science has to say on cosmology to the educated but diligent layman.

Lawrence Krauss in typical fashion, weaves a story of great readability, into the depths of recent cosmological thinking. Anyone with even the slightest scientific knowledge will appreciate this new addition to his work. I was in line this morning first thing and spent the day reading and re reading this book. His writing is concise, his breadth of knowledge seemingly infinite. No other hard science writer today, does what Krauss does with such an intricate topic. Taking up the mantle of public hero for the sciences, Krauss picks up where Sagan left off. Don't wait for tomorrow to get this book. Go out tonight and pick up this tomb of unparalleled wisdom!

I enjoyed reading this book after hearing an interview with the author on the radio and then deciding to order it.  It could have been shorter.  I thought it wondered a bit toward the middle...but this is a very big subject!  So,in my opinion, the author did an excellent job of writing about a complex topic in science at "just above" a layman's level.

Fabulous!  I read many parts of it twice.  There was a steep learning curve because I never took a physics course, but it was fascinating. I always suspected some of the concepts and I will read more of his books.  The author also has lectures on YouTube.

This is very well written by one of the leaders in cosmology, but requires some basic knowledge of quantum theory and particle physics to appreciate the information that is so well presented. It is not really a good choice for the casual reader.

Read this book twice. Thanks Prof. Your ideas are provoking and your logic needs more attention than I could pay the first time through. Marked the spots I wanted to reread and found it better to read through again.
A must read in the search for understanding existence. Just as the Origin of Species and the Selfish Gene are required reads to understand biology, so is this book to understand cosmology.

I never finished this book. The topic was fascinating but the delivery very dry and repetitive. If I were I an academic perhaps I'd have continued reading. Additionally I found the constant "authorship" references rather offensive.  The amount of time spent on "I did", "I said" and "I was proved Right" distracted greatly from the supposed topic and reason I chose the book. In fairness perhaps that's just the academics culture.

A lot of what Lawrence Krauss says in this book is good science, but his central conclusion seems, at least to me, to be inconsistent with the evidence.  He explains that virtual particles materialize in the empty space near electrons, but he concludes from this that the virtual particles jump into existence from nothing.  This conclusion, however, contradicts his more detailed explanation of how virtual particles come into being.  According to the explanation he gives, they are created by the quantum activity of the electrons that are present in space, and, according to science, electrons are something - not nothing.  He also concludes that virtual particles could jump in and out of existence within the empty space between galaxies just as they do within the space between electrons and protons - but again, like electrons and protons, galaxies are something, and their presence, according to the proton/electron analogy, is necessary for the creation of the virtual particles.  In addition, he says that empty space really isn’t empty.  It is full of dark matter and energy that we cannot see.  So again, if empty space is full of dark energy, virtual particles are not being created from nothing. But the whole point of the book (according to its title) is to show that something can be created from nothing (which one would assume means absolutely nothing instead of almost nothing or seemingly nothing).  And because this book is ultimately an attempt to claim that a god is not necessary to explain the big bang and the possible creation of our universe from absolutely nothing (no time, no space, no matter, no energy), I think the book fails.  Its ultimate conclusion does not correspond to the evidence it describes.
This book is one of my favorites! Dr. Krauss expanded my horizons.  Getting a taste  of physics and quantum theory was fun, enlightening and amazing.  Great book!

Here is a book for those who have an interest in exploring the wonders of the universe and the elements that comprise it.  It is not an easy read but it is a fascinating one to say the least.  Those who have a background in physics, and especially astrophysics, will have a leg up in grasping the explanations which Prof. Krauss presents in this book.  Personally, I have neither but still enjoyed the book and found it extremely interesting and educational.  He does not have much regard for those who are critical of his perspective based on the existence of a Supreme Being or Prime Mover.  God is a creation of the human mind and is left for the field of theology, not science.  If you have strong feelings about the existence of God, you will not appreciate this book.  For others, I think you will enjoy the trip.  I intend to re-read it in order to better grasp what Prof. Krauss discusses.
It was very easy to follow.  I think that after reading it, my ubderstanding of the big bang was very much clear.
I've read literally several hundred books on the topic of reality and physics and the nature of our universe, and this one ranks among the best.

Lawrence Krauss extends his excellent video into an updated version of the flat zero energy universe that emerges by the balancing out of negative energy of gravity and positive energy of through motion(inflation) and matter. As a result of this environment, quantum fluctuations , provided what was needed to create the solar systems and milky ways ,in these zero energy vacuum universes. Like Hawking ,he uses Feynman`s "sum of histories" or "sum of paths", a quantum concept for predicting the probability of virtual particles popping in out of existence on a subatomic level and transfers it to virtual universes popping into existence but zero energy allows these universes to stay in existence and bypass Heisenberg`s Law of Uncertainty. We therefore have a multiverse of universes. He uses these concepts with brilliance to illustrate why we do not need a creator and how the universe and it`s laws are self sustaining. These ideas and mathematics are a product of physicists over the last forty years from Professor Guth to Linde who were involved with the Chaotic Inflation and Alexander Vilenkin's Model of Cosmic Origins and Hawking. A great summary for the background of Cosmology is John Gribbin`s Cosmology for Beginners. <...>.  One thing I came away with was that nothing is not really nothing because the evidence indicates that there are laws and energies that embody and govern this nothingness.  Lawrence Krauss integrates all the ideas with humour and creativity to stimulate anyone with a desire to learn more about the Cosmos.

Aside from the odd title which has caused a great deal of confusion, especially by those who haven't bothered to read it, this book shows us how far science and scientific theory peels away the value of common sense to explain the universe. I do wish it had more allegory and metaphor to explain some of the more difficult concepts. Its hard to blame Krauss too much for brevity yet it is too brief. I wanted to know why the universe was flat based on images of background radiation and I wanted a few equations, their explanations and even if I was stupi fied by them, at least I could have had a go.
If you know somethings about science and the universe, then this read will be fasinating.
complicated book but the author did his best to get his message across in a funny way.

I have a deep and long abiding  interest in science  (especially Quantum Mechanics) but I have never formally studied the subject apart from the philosophy of science at undergraduate level. So I found some of the concepts a bit challenging. But the thesis is brilliant. Well written with a well reasoned clearly built up case. which finishes in the same void which the Buddha more than two millennium ago described as the origin of all things. Form is empty and emptiness is form said this wise old man. I feel sure having read his book that Lawrence Krauss would agree.

When this book actually addressed the subject-matter indicated by the title, it was profoundly disappointing.  The author, for instance, speculates on Aquinas' (and others') understanding of "nothing," suggesting that they probably meant "empty space" or something like it when they spoke of "nothing."  In other words, Krauss tries to get us to read his book based on the clam that he is going to address the question of "why there is something rather than nothing" but, then, defines "nothing" as "something," and has the audacity to claim that Aquinas and other agreed with him!  Not only is Krauss' claim about Aquinas false (Aquinas sees "nothing" as the absence of being altogether, hence it is a negation of being and not a "thing"), something he could have discovered rather easily if he had taken time to investigate it, but he leaves us without an answer to the question on the cover of his book by a sleight of hand move by changing the meaning of the word "nothing."  Once he gives "reality" to nothing he can then go on to speak of more reality coming from that "nothing" (which is really something and therefore able to serve as a substrate for other things).

I worked with a high energy physics research group (Trilling-Goldhaber group) Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory 1965-69.  This book is a classic. It gives the history and brings you up to date on what is going on in both elementary particle physics and cosmology.  Although this book is definitely for the expert, it can also be read by the non-expert because the author is a clear writer and does his best to make a very complex subject as clear as possible. You will be overwhelmed. Try it.

Lawrence Krauss explains how a universe could arise from 'nothing' and does so beautifully!  I've also seen the lecture he gave, and it was truly awe inspiring.  If you can come into this with a truly open mind and process the information he gives you, you will come away with a deeper and greater understanding and appreciation for the universe we live in and all the things science has done to make sense of it.  I would recommend this book to anyone, it is outstanding!

The book is a clear exposition of the implications of astrophysical findings to date.  Krauss explains the various theories that remain possible and why, together with a review of earlier theories now dis-proven by recent data.  This will provide understanding of current thinking in astrophysics for those with interest in these ideas but lacking in mathematical skills.  May be unsatisfying to those unprepared to align their beliefs with the evidence.

But, since I am not finished with it, I will hold my full comment until later. This is a good book for all to read but slightly dense for non science folks. Could be made slightly more ordinary reader capable. The information is real and exceptionally important for us to understand what the universe is made of and how we have analyzed and understood the info to date. More to come.

Amazing lesson in cosmology from Dr Krauss. The diagrams are lacking on the kindle but the narrative is a good combination of the history of discovery and the fundamentals even if the physics can be confusing for the under-educated like myself.

If you care about debates around god, the universe and the cause of it all or you are just a science buff, this is a book for you. Krauss explores and explains the sometimes murky physics and math behind our understanding of the origin of the universe with clear visible examples and patient explanations. It is a great reminder of just how much we know,  how much we don't and about where it, and we, came from.
I like Prof. Lawrence's view of modern cosmology.

Early man could not understand how the world always was, so someone came up with the idea that God made it.  But God was posited as having always been.  Not much progress here.  Krauss explains in fairly plain language why it is reasonable to believe the definition of empty space is not truly empty.  In part: since energy and matter can interchange, things can arise from empty space because of the massless energy contained there.  We have long known that the gods do not cause lightning, thunder and floods.  They are also not needed for sub atomic particles and the strong and weak attractions.  There is something rather than nothing because it is just there.  We have found it, measured it and work with it every day.  It is very likely eternal...but in changing forms.  Much simpler than a pantheon of gods and saints who initiate and control it.  All you have to do is study it.  Much more reliable and predictable than supernatural beings exercising their whims.
I enjoyed the book quite a bit.  The chronology of the universe up to present era is fascinating.  Somewhat too detailed in some sections, but acceptable.

From now on, we will never have a serious ontological discussion without mentioning this book. We will look back at this book like a monument to science beginning to pull together one more gap of understanding. Agree or disagree--you must own this book.

This book is written in a fashion that anyone can understand, but that doesn't take anything from it's depth. You will come away with an appreciation for the beauty of physics and an expanded sense of awe at the complexity of the universe.

As usual, Krauss delivers a highly-readable book on a subject of profound importance to both scientists and non-scientists. For anyone who has ever wondered about why the universe is the way it is, this is a good starting point.

The wonders of the universe explained in a down to Earth way, with a genuine sense of humor and clear style. It is not always an easy read for the interested layman, but it inspires to learn more. Much recommended.

Charismatic, and eye opening! Something from nothing is a much needed exhortation, that will not only cause you to question why you believe what you believe, but how you came to believe in it in the first place.

Krauss presents a great summary of the Standard Model and it's predictions, verifictaion, and implications for the universe and its inhabitants.  Ricjhard Dawkinf delivers a great summary in his afterword..
I like to be challenged in my thinking.  This book does just that and in a well written, easy to follow manner.  Nice analogies and explanations that the layman can digest and follow.
This is an excellent layman's overview of the question, "What caused the Big Bang?"  Yes, science does have a hypothesis and Dr. Krauss explains it all very well.  I highly recommend his book.

This is one of the best books about science and modern physics that I've read in a long time. Although I recommend at least a somewhat understanding of general/special relativity as well as quantum mechanics, it's not inherently required to enjoy this book. Lawrence Krauss is a personal hero of mine, and an icon that I follow in my studies as an undergrad in nuclear physics and processing research. He does a fantastic job of bringing the complex concepts within theoretical physics down to a laymen's view just as easily. He explains the evidence for Dark Matter and how it relates to the formation and ultimate structure of galaxies. Also explaining Dark Energy on simple terms and how it compares to the cosmological constant and how Einstein tried working it into his early equations when first working on his general theory of relativity. Doctor Krauss also addresses the current ideas in String Theory, not necessarily mocking it, but validating its strong parts and eventually revealing it as not testable. While I don't want to reveal too much about the book, his scientific prowess really shines when he explains the origin of the universe and explaining the evidence of the Big Bang and how the laws of physics explain the mechanics of the early inflation that happened and how it relates to the age, size, and now accelerating universe.
This book is not just a good discussion on the qualities of nothingness and how something can arise from it, but is also good at explaining our current understanding of the Universe.
This book is simply amazing. After reading I have a much deeper understanding of the subject matter and am delighted that this was assigned reading for one of my classes.
I learned something new and amazing about science and the universe on every page.  Its a fun story about how the universe has surprised the worlds greatest physicists.

I think Lawrence Krauss is a great scientist with a brilliant mind, and I do believe he has written an excellent book that will bring inquiring minds pretty much up to date with the state of particle physics.  That said, I also believe he is a rank amateur in the field of theology, and I wish for his sake and other's that he would spend some "earnest" time learning the fundamentals of that area before he truly contemplates committing to the atheism he seems so glibly to embrace.  For all his fervor for the detached scientific approach to understanding where we stand in the cosmos, he seems impishly silent, and a bit intellectually dishonest, when he argues for there being "empty space" from which a universe can be spawned.  He more or less admits to this fact in the book, acknowledging that nothing really isn't nothing, but the very fact that he says as much demonstrates that his theological stance is a weak one indeed.  Still, I believe his beautiful explanations of the revelations of the world's greatest modern physicists and astronomers warrants a five-star rating, even if the theological special pleading, most of which is only a distraction, is pretty lame.
This is a very good book if you are interested in the subject. I would recommend watching some youtube videos featuring Krauss on this subject while you read the book.
He's a great expository writer and he's got plenty of nice witticisms and anecdotes to keep an inherently compelling story extra engaging and fun.
While still very high level, it helps understand things that were before merely questions in my mind. Thank you Mr. Krauss

The book is a good update on modern cosmology. Dr. Krauss presents the subject matter in a very readable and exciting way. Unfortunately he spend too much time and effort trying to make the case against religion or the existence of God for that matter.  If your already friendly towards his views you will find that part of the book to offer little new insights and if not, you will probably find his arguments unconvincing - I suspect most people reading this book will fall into the former category anyway.
This book is very interesting. A bit technical, but Kraus explains how the big bang happened and what happened afterward.
Terrific writing on a spectacular and mind-expanding subject.  He made it so that even a lowly doctor can understand it.

I hadn't heard of Lawrence Krauss until I viewed the documentary "The Unbelievers".  I was impressed enough with his intelligence, knowledge, and humanity to check out this book, which was mentioned in the movie.  I just completed the book and could personally only give it 3 stars.  I'll admit it straight out:  I couldn't understand most of it.  There were passages and pages that made sense, and he writes conversationally, so I got thru the book; however, upon putting it down I knew I would be unable to tell anyone anything about it.  It helped that I had reviewed a set of Teaching Company CDs called "Particle Physics for Non-Physicists", which I recommend, but even that background was insufficient.  To those of you who did understand it, I salute you.  Maybe one day I'll try it again.
Lawrence is one of the greatest minds of our time, can recommend anything by him to be a great use of anyone's time!
this guy is brilliant. and he proved to me, that all of this, could literally come out of nothing.

I enjoyed this. For the lay person it takes you beyond where "Brief History" and "Universe in a Nutshell" gets you. Most of it can be absorbed on the first pass, some may require a little more thought. I'm not sure how much of the content is controversial vs accepted facts so while I feel like I'm probably now comparatively up-to-date on basic cosmology I don't know if I have an accurate, or as-accurate as we can now be, view of the universe(s), or just one author's pet theories. We are still on a journey, not at a destination (yet) in our understanding so I'd imagine much of this work will stand even if some of it turns out to be replaced by better theories.
Great reading except that he has an axe to grind rather than a point to prove. Great book. R.

Lawrence Krauss does an excellent job in this book.  It is a book that will require you to think, and do some homework on the concepts it introduces to appreciate it fully. I put this book in my pile of books to digest, and read again in a year or two. I quite literally stopped playing Battlefield 3, reading my magazine subscriptions, and work on my thesis until I had finished it.  Fascinating. Thank you Mr. Krauss! It is also worthwhile to view his lecture on this topic available on youtube.

Professor Krauss is clearly knowledgable about the subject of the book and does a reasonable job of bringing genius level concepts down to above-average intelligence level comprehension. I handed it to a person of lesser sophistication but who was still interested in space and astronomy and they found it to be greek. Also, he constantly poked jabs at creationists. While I understood the impulse, the attitude kind of read as elitist and after the 50th or so reference I found it a bit grating. Overall, a good read if you did well in high school or undergrad level science, and you aren't some thin-skinned creationist.
Very informative. Reads great.  He makes it very engaging and writes very well.

I had the good fortune to be in attendance when Prof. Krauss presented his excellent "A Universe From Nothing' talk at the AAI conference in 2009. This book expands on that topic and provides an excellent and enjoyable read. I am happy to recommend this book wholeheartedly.

Ive read alot of the reviews and I probably can't top them for verbosity. All I can say.. for the avid science reader this book is fantastic. There are lots of so-so books about physics and cosmololgy but this one really explains current thinking in an understandable way. It combines the theory of evolution and the multiverse to explain how to get here from nowhere. Follow it chapter by chapter and suddenly so say OH!"

This is truly a captivating and informative book. I went into it with little to no knowledge of the wondrous Universe we call home. This book informed me in a comprehensive, and well written manner and i recommend it to friends and family constantly. Well worth the read! I am now an avid reader of similar titles.
Thank you
Straight up facts with his usual entertaining style. Well done

Many of us refuse to simply accept that what we don't yet understand must come from "God".  There is no proof of a divine being.  Yet we are uncomfortable simply rejecting the concept of god since we were indoctrinated as to God's existence from our earliest childhood memories.  This book gives rational reasons as to why there is something from nothing and that a divine being is not necessary to explain why there is something rather than nothing.
One of my most favorite books of all time. Just fascinating.

I read this a couple of months ago and am still thinking of several of the concepts. Krauss does an excellent job in carefully explaining difficult concepts, and fairly represents the various (thin) arguments against his science based ideas.

The only reason I didn't give this five stars is because there was some technical stuff here and there I couldn't follow. My fault, not his.  It is a remarkably enlightening book. You can't go wrong with it.
Hard to understand. Promises more than delivers.  I will read it again to see if there is more to it.

Krauss has a wonderful gift for making complicated subjects understandable. But then he uses his platform to publicly argue and sneer at fundamentalist theists who don't want to learn. The book would have been better to end with the sense of wonder that it created in the reader, instead of schoolyard taunting.

Well written for the layperson.  Takes a complex subject and explains it piece by piece so that it begins to open up yor thought processes.  Even if you don't know a quark from a qua ck  you will enjoy this book

It is astonishing that we are gathering so much information regarding the universe and there are brilliant minds that are able to provide solutions to this data.  Persons who enjoy astrophysics and the increasing amount of proof supporting Big Bang Theory would really enjoy this read.

Enjoyed reading but the science is challenging to follow. I'm no dummy (undergrad & grad degrees in engineering). That being said, it made me ponder the concept of "nothingness". Almost makes my head spin when I meditate on it.....

The book didn't add much to my knowledge of the Universe, but it was interesting and there were a few worthwhile facts I didn't know.  It also gave a good layman's explanation of the relation between subatomic particles and the Universe.  (Also, it helped me to understand a few things they talk about on "The Big Bang Theory"!

What I thought was a book about nothingness and existence turned out to be the last 1/4 of this book, with 3/4 of its content in the beginning explaining the modern picture of the universe with all the understood modern physics. Granted all that explanation was needed to understand the bigger picture of the something from nothing argument, but it really mostly felt like a book explaining the modern view of the universe.

Extremely readable and enjoyable book.  The reader will come away with a tremendous understanding of dark energy, quantum gravity, and the creation of the universe from nothing.  Plus it will raise many interesting ideas that science points to such as the multi-verse.

I have read this several times now, and each time I get more out of it. I might need to learn more about quantum mechanics and particle physics. But the picture he is presenting is sufficiently consistent with known facts for me to be convinced he is on the right track. I look forward to the next installment.

I'm not sure what his problem is, but unfortunately, mixed in with what would otherwise be a decent explanation of the universe and how things are, and yes WHY they are, Krauss also seems compelled to a) bash religion as a recurring theme, b) present disparaging commentary of famous astronomers such as Hubble, and c) leave totally un-named the famous, Nobel prize winning astrophysicists Penzias and Wilson, the discoverers of the Cosmic Background Radiation (CMBR). Here are his words: "One of the many remarkable things about the cosmic microwave radiation is that it was discovered in New Jersey, of all places, by two scientists who really didn't have the slightest idea what they were looking for." That's it, no names.  But he does go on to refer to them as "hapless" and later to say that David Wilkinson was one of the physicists that should have discovered the CMBR, "had they not been scooped by the Bell Labs scientists".  I mean that just sounds like simply petty and childish.  The book is reasonably good at explaining things, yet I find Krauss a bit arrogant, self-serving, and unprofessional.  Unfortunate.  I'll take Neil Degrass Tyson over Krauss any day.
Have not finished book. So far I find it very interesting. The math involved is complicated but then again it should be.
readable, understandable, grasping, witty, touches latest in physics and cosmology, and more importantly, its science and the truth... just read the foreword from Richard Dawkins.
Very technical but altogether fascinating.
An exceptional book that discusses the development of modern cosmology in terms a layman can comprehend.  Anyone interested in the sceintific method and the universe we live it will benefit from it.

This was a intellectual exciting book, The author explains everything with such precise and lucid detail one with not such a strong background in the sciences can understand and ride along the journey to view the world on a whole new perspective!

Admittedly that isn't quite the throat-grabber a publisher likes on a dust-jacket.  But--and why one has to point this out again and again and again to persons of a naturalist bent I cannot imagine--the transition from one physical state, describable by mathematical laws and comprising quantum functions, to another physical state is NOT the transition from nothing into a universe.  It leaves entirely untouched the venerable philosophical question of why there is something rather than nothing, and so the book is just one huge philosophical non sequitur.  I propose that henceforth that it should be legally required of any physicist who wants to write on ontological issues that he or she must first complete at least a Master's program in the history of philosophy and a Doctoral program in philosophical ontology.
